replies.text:
When Anthony Hopkins played Colonel John Frost in A Bridge Too Far the real Colonel Frost was with them during shooting. Frost had a word with Hopkins and the director, Richard Attenborough, about a scene where he was depicted running and ducking  for cover going from guard post to guard post under heavy fire. He told them that he did NOT run, but instead 'walked briskly'. Hopkins asked if that meant they were depicting the enemy fire as too heavy.

"Oh no," replied Frost "It was just as bad. But it wouldn't be done to run like that in front of the men"

To be a British officer you clearly needed to be asbolutely mad.  (And, incidentally, Attenborough left the scene as it was, explaining that "Reality just wasn't believable" in that case)

replies.text:
John Roberts I'd actually say that that's not true. We can argue about WWI not actually being a world war, but just Europe fucking things up once again, but in WWII there is Japan as a big part of the axis powers that participate right from the start, or actually started earlier. Yes, from an American or European perspective the focus was on Europe and the Atlantic, but that's for Europe itself the case because that was what occupied everyone's lives and is still visible in every major city and for the US because after Pearl Harbor they had to choose what theater to concentrate their forces on and deemed Nazi Germany as the greater thread (and rightly so). That however doesn't mean the Pacific theater wasn't just as horrifying and devastating. It's just not what Western nations usually focus on when discussing WWII. Once again: Europe because they have their own shit to deal with, the US probably because there is some internalized guilt for the atomic bombings (Which, imo is bs, but that's a different topic).
As far as Africa, the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent were concerned. That was mainly colonialism running its due course. With maybe the exception of North Africa, as Germany just attacked them as well, so one could argue that fights there would've been inevitable. Btw, you know who also didn't really have a whole lot to do in causing the war? Our little buddy Poland. That didn't really change the fact that the war came there first, did it?
We can talk about decolonization and the founding of international agencies like the UN and the flaws in that, but that would be too far of a stretch.
Point being: Large parts of all armies participating in WWII were non-white. The people who claim WWII as a 'white man's war' usually don't want to point to who initiated it, but want to brush over the many many men and women that died fighting against (I mean, some also fought for, but again, different topic) Nazism, despite it not being their responsibility. And many of these people were volunteers. And that's a problem. Especially when you then go on to look at how these people or their descendants were being treated when they came to Europe 20 years later, when the last Colonies were finally being broken up. And how their descendants are still being treated now. Because when you look at Racism in modern day Europe, it's usually white/local people against immigrants. Though nowadays the debate is usually centered around Refugees, it's actually about those descendants. The small bit that still reminds you of colonialism. And that IS outrageous.
This is why I don't think WWII was a 'white man's war'. The initiators weren't exclusively white. The soldiers weren't exclusively white. And nowadays the term is being used by Racists to fence themselves off from people that are different.
Sorry for the long comment, thanks for reading and have a nice day.

author: @niknelson2464
text:
I've got a propaganda poster from the second world war on my wall, and it's a British one. The caption reads "Together". It has white British soldiers, Canadian RCAF troops, Indian troops, and African troops.

Not to mention the French, who apparently saw it as a point of pride that they had colonial troops in their armed forces, hosting many parades featuring them.

It was the US that was against integrated forces, and even forbade the French from allowing any colonial troops into 2nd Armoured Division, as the US didn't want any coloured folks in their propaganda photos/were just racist in general.

Three Arrows more or less mentions this, but I figured I'd drop my two cents.

replies.author: @Frserthegreenengine
replies.text: @The Icon of SinActually not strictly true, especially regarding the British. He was popular with the public and the officers but not the average soldier, sailor or airman.

author: @TheRagingK
text:
There were some amazing feats by French black colonial troops called the Tirailleurs S√©n√©galais during WW1.  Various observers of these troops mentioned their extraordinarily high morale for the conditions they were in.  

There was also the 369th Infantry Regiment of the US army during WW1 more commonly known as the Harlem Hellfighters.  Young and old black men from the United States fought with the French army who would accept black troops because of their manpower shortages.  Here's a quote on one of their accomplishments.  

On 25 September 1918 the Fourth French Army went on the offensive in conjunction with the American drive in the Meuse‚ÄìArgonne. The 369th turned in a good account in heavy fighting, though they sustained severe losses. The unit captured the important village of S√©chault. At one point the 369th advanced faster than French troops on their right and left flanks, and risked being cut off. By the time the regiment pulled back for reorganization, it had advanced 14 kilometres (8.7 mi) through severe German resistance.  

I'd say that's some pretty significant accomplishment for a "inferior" people as many beloved athletes the time.  Men are men and women are women no matter their skin tone.  Just because their different doesn't mean that they are less than others.  

I went into WW1 specifically because of my interest in it but i'm sure with some research anyone could find more cases of black armies being equal to or superior to others.

replies.author: @aharreld2340
replies.text:
Neanis, you do get that the "Western" way of life is dependent on oppressing people in the 'third world,' overworking them for cheap labor, and stealing their resources, right? Though, such methods are also applied at home and the *majority* of people are actually worse off. Most positive changes in material conditions are more due to advances in technology and the organization of complex systems than capitalism itself (which has leached off of both to advance the interests of the capitalist class). 

And no, not every person that is rich is bad. Marx and Engels, for instance, were both bourgeois and thus class traitors. They were alright. The issue is that in order to be rich one must have, at some point have oppressed their fellows and robbed them or to have inherited such stolen goods down the line (eg, colonialism, slavery, neo-colonialism, genocide, etc). These 'thefts' are often times made 'legal' because the rich have had greater access to political lines of power. And in order for us to make life more equitable, democratic, plain livable, etc the means of production will need to be owned by the workers/community and capital redistributed. A majority of the wealthy, along with their lapdogs, will attempt everything in their power to squash such attempts. 

And I wouldn't say 'never' in regards to 'socialist' states either. Cuba is a stunning success. I say stunning, because despite *constant* attempts at sabotage, sanctions, etc the country has a 99% literacy rating, medical care for all, etc. Many of its issues are due to its context as a country under siege and *not* due to it being a 'socialist' state. It has managed to stay standing while many similar projects have fallen so obviously it has done a lot of things right in that context.

Though, honestly, the whole intent of socialism and communism is to destroy the state, so to go, "Point to a socialist state that has been successful" is a bit ludicrous and missing the point. If such a project were to be achieved we wouldn't be talking about states to begin with. As it is the states who have pursued socialism have had more just systems *despite* constant attempts (and successes) at sabotage by external forces, like the US, IMF, or certain European states. And to just hit this point home, why don't you compare and contrast the material conditions (for the majority) in Eastern Europe during the time it was under the USSR vs the time it has been subservient to Western Europe. I'm not talking about GDP here, but things like access to healthcare, food, employment, etc and what continued access to these resources means for the people living there.

And if that weren't enough socialism appears to be the go to system for societies that have minimal hierarchies. EG, your hunter-gatherers, your horticulturists and pastoralists, etc. And archaeological evidence points to there being some early city-states that went with some early forms of anarchy/socialism.

And to hammer it all home: About 20 million a year die due to preventable causes under capitalism. That's just the *preventable* stuff and not all the wars waged, infrastructure destroyed, etc in order to maintain the global status quo.

replies.author: @neco9590
replies.text:
@03041976001 what about the portrayal of women or non-white people in WW2 (specifically in WW2 combat) makes a mockery of history?

women: apart from millions of women in non-combat-roles around the world on both sides many participating forces saw women at least volunteer for auxiliary forces and also engage in combat (the most common role seeming to be that of an anti-aircraft-operator, although some armies saw many women participating in all fields of active combat (most prominently the Soviet Union's army). Also worthy of mention are the several resistance movements that basically took what they could get, in terms of everything from equipment to members (aka they were composed of fighters of both sexes).

non-white people: apart from obvious theaters of war such as Africa or the whole conflict between japan and china (which WERE obviously part of WW2, allowing for the label WORLD war) there were a lot of people of color fighting in Europe, most prominently parts of the British Indian Army (sidenote: The Nazis btw recruited indian POW's for their own little indian army) and, of course, the Senegalese Tirailleurs, featured in one of the stories based on true events from the very game we theoretically discuss here, who fought with the french until the french liberation (before being replaced).

Oh, and to really quick hit on the second "controversial" singleplayer-mission of the game that theoretically was in discussion here: the norwegian resistance obviously included women and the Norwegian sabotage of German attempts to acquire heavy water also occurred. Based on truth, although not displaying or claiming to display exact moments in history accurately. (In fact the setup was even relatively close, since there was a failed attempt to attack a facility by some SOE-backed Norwegians and, if I remember this correctly a similar event gets mentioned in the beginning of that mission)

replies.author: @KingBobXVI
replies.text:
I remember this happening way back with _Super Smash Bros. 4_ too (well, it's happening _all the fucking time,_ I've just since been tuning it out).


An image from the game was posted showing the character Zero Suit Samus' new costume, which basically amounted to booty-shorts and a sports bra. The anti-SJW crowd went bonkers - thousands of comments complaining about "the inevitable backlash" from "SJWs", people saying why "it's totally ok, guys" and how they "aren't misogynists for liking it" and if they _are_ then by golly so be it, blog posts and articles preemptively written to _defend_ the costume, pointing out "no no, it's totally practical wear for a fighting game" and "it has precedence! See, it's from this old game! It's not misogynistic!"


Literally no one ever actually complained about the outfit, outside of some saying the character's boots from the previous game had a better design.


They manufacture straw-SJWs to attack to keep their outrage mill going, and they have to invent them because there isn't enough of an _actual_ opposition for them to fight. Then when the rhetoric is established, they started latching it to every bit of media they conceivably could - a director cast a woman? SJWs. A game has a female character? SJWs. Girls at gaming or comic conventions? _PURE SJW INVASION!_


It's absurd.

replies.author: @jellyunicorn8347
replies.text:
the ethiopians wouldn't have won if italy didn't gas them either way. the reason why ethiopia won the first war was because italy invaded with only some 20000 troops or so against an overwhelming amount of ethiopians. they were also supported by the UK and france, who didn't want italy to become a competitor as a colonial power.

the second war was a whole different beast. while they were still outnumbered, they were at much better odds in terms of numerical superiority and had complete air supremacy as well as tanks. the ethiopians meanwhile had essentially ancient equipment, with 4 old tanks compared to italy's 795, 13 biplanes compared to italy's 595, and mostly very old rifles. sometimes they didn't have rifles at all. mussolini was very serious about having an italian east africa in the horn of africa. ethiopia was barely industrialised and could not hold a candle to any industrialised european country who puts a serious attempt in invading them, which the italians did.

one might try to refute this by arguing that the ethiopians did have a successful counter offensive in the christmas offensive. however, the ethiopians didn't actually achieve an operational victory at the offensive - their (overly ambitious) plan was to split the italians at eritrea, but it stopped short and stalled. this was not the result of the italians gassing the ethiopian troops, but because of their massive material advantage. the reason for the slow italian advance was that de bono didn't want to overextend italian troops and minimise losses. perhaps without the use of gas the italians would've won slower, but win they would nonetheless.

author: @syystomu
text: When I was in Paris in... I think it was 2014, I visited the Carnavalet Museum and they had a Liberation of Paris photography exhibition going on at the time which was apparently an exhibition they'd done decades ago before (maybe it was even as far back as the 40's? The details are escaping me rn) and some sections of it were dedicated to the things they'd neglected during the first run of the exhibition. Part of that was the women and the people of colour who had participated in the liberation. Photographs and even some film reels of them had been included to fix the earlier exclusion. I found it really refreshing, getting to see pictures of heroism in the war that weren't all just of white men.

author: @charliedawson4877
text: My family has a proud military history. My great grandfather was court marshalled twice. Once for stealing fuel from the air force and the other time for driving a fork lift off a jeti. We also executed deserters. But that's my mum's side. My dad's grandad was actually at Dunkirk. He tried to swim back and got lost in the ocean. Luckily he found his way back to shore, Unluckily it was miles into enemy territory and he thought operation Dynamo was over. He spent the rest of the war hiding out in France. When he got back my great grandmother had remarried though and had kids. Luckily she ditched her husband and kids and married him. God bless us.

author: @lucofparis4819
text:
I'm fascinated by the american wilful ignorance of historical events they otherwise constantly refer to. And yeah, it was a World War, and Africa itself was a significant theatre of operations even in the early years of the war.
And in mainland Europe, battalions from the colonies were definitely stationed there. In fact, this practice was already in place WW1. A number of units indigenous of different parts of the world are integral parts of French history, from the trench warfare of WW1 to D-Day onwards, and are dutifully honoured with monuments to their bravery and all that you'd expect.

text: In addition to the well-covered colonial troops from the French and British empires, it's also important to note the presence of large numbers of Central Asians who served in the Soviet military on the Eastern front. author: @Inerrant1
text:
Oh god, 2 minutes into your video and I couldn't handle his video.

As a white male American tired of this bullshit, I have spent quite some time researching the most neglected aspects of WW2; the Japanese invasion of China, wherein as much as twenty million Chinese died. They fought in WW2 for 8 years- before the invasion of Poland and after the defeat of Nazi Germany. I do not believe Imperial Japan could have been defeated without their contribution, at least not in 1945. As much as 39% of the casualties suffered by Imperial Japanese Soldiers is attributed not to the USMC or the British in Burma but to the Chinese. American marines approached Iwo Jima fighting a nation that had allocated 80% of its manpower to the mainland. Just imagine how much worse it could have been for them there....

I visited two former WAC (Women's Army Corps) pilots in Hawaii at around 2010, both of whom have since passed away, both of whom flew cargo in the Pacific and did encounter the enemy. I attended the funeral of the latter one in Arlington cemetery where she was given a 21 gun salute and full honors. Now, she was never public with her personal life- but the two women lived together and alone since WW2. Whatever implications you want to make from that, feel free. I'd wager those ladies were braver than any ignorant youtuber talking bullshit about wars he knows nothing about.

You already mentioned the African troops in the Free French which, if I recall, I do believe there was one French soldier in the film who had dark skin and I noted it at the time with a bit of a nod. Not to mention that Ethiopia resisted Italy since 1935- it was the first country to be attacked by any of the Axis powers in Europe and they gave up 100,000 souls for the cause.

text: I thought this video was very good, I also thought that No Bullshits video was very good, I think to the average person that is uninformed hearing a compelling argument is enough to convince them, and false information can be believed just as easily as true information if the people watching don't take the time to learn about the subject themselves. It has become more and more common for right-leaning channels to be lazy about the content that they produce and in cases like this, they can be clearly seen to mess up. However, although he was wrong about the specifics of the Dunkirk situation, I believe the point he was trying to make in his video was that there shouldn't be forced diversity. Diversity should be something that happens naturally instead of an agenda. I think this relates to the idea you shouldn't give preferential treatment to someone based off of their race; agendas that require a specific race of actor solely to fill a diversity quota are acting in a racist manner.  Anyways I thought your video was great, just wanted to point out I think thats the larger point he was adressing.
